results.title: Nathalie Granger
results.brief_description:
With little or no embellishment, film-maker Marguerite Duras offers a simple, often wordless chronicle of a woman’s day. She and her friend are seen doing yard work, talking about their families and receiving the occasional visitor. The brightest spot in the day is when a washing machine salesman comes to call.

Credits: Producer, Luc Moullet ; director, Marguerite Duras ; writer, Marguerite Duras ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet ; music, Marguerite Duras ; editor, Nicole Lubtchansky ; other crew, Benoit Jacquot, Bruno Nuytten, Michel Vionnet.
Cast: Jeanne Moreau, Lucia Bose, Gerard Depardieu, Valerie Mascolo, Dionys Mascolo, Luce Garcia-Ville.

results.title: Natasha
results.creator_credit: Derek Bailey, Robin Scott, Julia Matheson, BBC-TV and National Video Corporation
results.brief_description: Documentary featuring internationally acclaimed Russian born ballet dancer, Natalia Makarova. Natalia introduces and provides a brief background to each of the ballet excerpts included in this dance documentary demonstrating that not only is she a wonderful dancer but also she possesses a charming and humorous personality. Her partners include Anthony Dowell, Denys Ganio, Gary Chryst, Tim Flavin, and the Norman Maen Dancers supported by the music of the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Barry Wordsworth. In 1983 Natalia won a Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical.

results.title: Natalie Kalmus
results.brief_description: When studios hired Technicolor cameras and equipment, they also hired Natalie Kalmus. During the glory days of Technicolor’s three-strip process, between 1934 and 1955, she was the colour supervisor on over 400 films, including The Wizard of Oz (1939).

constellations_primary.name: Communicating colour
constellations_primary.description: An exploration of colour on-screen inspired by Technicolor supervisor, Natalie Kalmus.

results.description:
When studios hired Technicolor cameras and equipment, they also hired Natalie Kalmus. During the glory days of Technicolor’s three-strip process, between 1934 and 1955, she was the colour supervisor on over 400 films, including The Wizard of Oz (1939) and Gone with the Wind (1939).

After seeing filmmakers use the earlier two-strip Technicolor process to produce “unnatural and disastrous results”, she urged filmmakers to employ “colour restraint”. Kalmus believed that colour theories used in paintings could also be used in film and encouraged filmmakers to carefully consider which colours would convey a story’s emotions and themes.
description_for_label:
When studios hired Technicolor cameras and equipment, they also hired Natalie Kalmus. During the glory days of Technicolor’s three-strip process, between 1934 and 1955, she was the colour supervisor on over 400 films, including The Wizard of Oz (1939) and Gone with the Wind (1939).

After seeing filmmakers use the earlier two-strip Technicolor process to produce “unnatural and disastrous results”, she urged filmmakers to employ “colour restraint”. Kalmus believed that colour theories used in paintings could also be used in film and encouraged filmmakers to carefully consider which colours would convey a story’s emotions and themes.

results.title: Nat "King" Cole plus the Mills Brothers and Delta Rhythm Boys, 1943-1951
results.brief_description: Using archival resources which have been digitally restored, this video presented by Cab Calloway features a wonderful selection of jazz greats performed by the unique voice of the charming and memorable Nat “King” Cole, along with the Mills Brothers and the Delta Rhythm Boys and supported by Dorothy Dandridge, the Joey Adams Orchestra, Irving Ashby, Joe Comfort and Jack Costanza. NB: Fluctuating sound and picture quality.

results.title: Nasty love = L'Amore molesto
results.creator_credit: Mario Martone, Kermit Smith, Andrea Occhipinti, Angelo Curti, Lucky Red and Teatri Uniti
results.brief_description: A woman goes to investigate her mother’s apparent suicide and ends up having to face the grim reality of her past. Amalia, the sixty-something mother of Delia, is found dead on the beach, when she should have been on her way to visit Delia in Bologna. Delia, wanting to know why her mother killed herself, journeys back to Naples to discover the truth. She encounters her mother’s supposed lover and his son, as well as her estranged father. As she continues to explore, she must face the fact that her relationship with her mother was based on jealousy and disgust as much as it was on love. She must also face up to a terrible lie she told as a child, one that questioned her mother’s fidelity and ruined the lives of everyone around her. In Italian with English subtitles. Cast includes Anna Bonaiuto, Angela Luce, Gianni Cajafa and Giovanni Viglietti.

results.title: Nasser: people's pharaoh
results.creator_credit: New York Times Productions and Nielsen-Ferns
results.brief_description: Part of the Leaders of the twentieth century: portraits of power series. Examines Nasser’s rise to power in 1952 and his life as leader of Egypt during the 1950s and 1960s. Uses contemporary footage to provide insight into a number of events such as the Suez crisis (1956) and the Six Day War (1967). Narrated by Henry Fonda. Suitable for upper secondary level.
